Knowledge based on observation and experience rather than reason alone.
It was developed by Thomas Aquinas and earlier by Aristotle.
The argument from motion: everything in motion is moved by something else so there must be a first unmoved mover.
The argument from causation: every effect has a cause so there must be a first uncaused cause.
The argument from contingency: contingent beings depend on a necessary being for existence.

Front: Why does Aquinas reject infinite regress?
Back: Because without a first cause there would be no subsequent causes.

Front: What is meant by a necessary being?
Back: A being that must exist and cannot fail to exist.

Front: Why is the Cosmological Argument inductive?
Back: Because it draws a probable conclusion based on observation not logical certainty.

Front: One strength of the Cosmological Argument?
Back: It is based on empirical evidence and common human experience.

Front: One weakness of the Cosmological Argument?
Back: It assumes everything must have a cause which may not apply to the universe.

Front: What is the Kalam Cosmological Argument?
Back: A modern version arguing the universe began to exist and therefore has a cause.

Front: Who developed the Kalam Cosmological Argument?
Back: It was developed by Al-Ghazali and later William Lane Craig.

Front: How does science challenge the Cosmological Argument?
Back: Quantum physics suggests some events may be uncaused.

Front: Does the Cosmological Argument prove the God of classical theism?
Back: No it does not prove that the first cause has the attributes of the Christian God.
